data.title: Remembering Ray Charles with 10 interesting facts about the pioneer of 'soul music'
data.meta_description: Read on to know some fun facts about American singer-songwriter Ray Charles, who pioneered 'soul music' genre.
data.text:
Legendary American singer-composer Ray Charles was born on September 23 in the year 1930.

Charles pioneered the genre of 'soul music' in the 1950s by combining rhythm, blues, jazz and gospels.

He died on June 10, 2004 due to acute liver disease.

Here are 10 facts about 'The Genius' Ray Charles:

1. 'Georgia On My Mind', 'I Got A Woman', 'Unchain My Heart' and 'Hit the Road Jack' are some of the greatest hits of Ray Charles.

advertisement

2. Charles suffered from glaucoma as a child, which made him completely blind by the time he turned seven.

3. After moving to Orlando, Charles lived in utter poverty and went without food for days, since that was an extremely difficult time for musicians to find work.

4. Ray Charles Robinson dropped his last name to avoid confusion with the boxer, Sugar Ray Robinson.

5. He was a favourite of former US President Richard Nixon.

6. His compositions earned him the nicknames 'The Genius' and 'The High Priest of Soul'.

7. He was caught backstage with marijuana and drug paraphernalia and was arrested on charges of drug abuse in 1950.

8. He was arrested again on a narcotics charge while he was waiting in his hotel room, just before a performance.

9. Ray Charles spent a year in jail. After his release, he released 'Let's Go Get Stoned' to protest his conviction.

10. Rolling Stone magazine ranked him number 10 on their list of '100 Greatest Artists of All Time' and number two on the list of '100 Greatest Singers of All Time'.
